fields.summary: euca2ools does not verify ssl certificate by default if target is not AWS

status.description: This issue has been validated/reproduced, but has not been prioritized yet.
status.name: Confirmed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: Proxy should be verifying CLC's ssl cert in cases when CA-signed certificate is installed on CLC and possibly, self-signed, by checking for a particular certificate/public key.
fields.summary: user console proxy should have an option to verify CLC's ssl cert

comments.body:
I looked into this and it seems that boto already validates the certs, but I'm not sure what it does. Here's the method signature we call to get a connection object. That last line shows that validate_certs defaults to True.

class EC2Connection(AWSQueryConnection):

    APIVersion = boto.config.get('Boto', 'ec2_version', '2012-08-15')
    DefaultRegionName = boto.config.get('Boto', 'ec2_region_name', 'us-east-1')
    DefaultRegionEndpoint = boto.config.get('Boto', 'ec2_region_endpoint',
                                            'ec2.us-east-1.amazonaws.com')
    ResponseError = EC2ResponseError

    def __init__(self, aws_access_key_id=None, aws_secret_access_key=None,
                 is_secure=True, host=None, port=None,
                 proxy=None, proxy_port=None,
                 proxy_user=None, proxy_pass=None, debug=0,
                 https_connection_factory=None, region=None, path='/',
                 api_version=None, security_token=None,
                 validate_certs=True):

When debugging a running proxy, it looks like https_connection.CertValidatingHTTPSConnection is never called from AWSAuthConnection.new_http_connection because self.https_validate_certificates is set to False.
Vika, Could you be more specific about where that gets set to False? I looked through code and it defaults to True and I could not see where we overrode that.

David, I don't know why and where it's set to False (I saw that it should be True by default in the current version of boto), but at the point when it's used in the new_http_connection it's False. The problem might be related to the version of boto that we use as EC2Connection in the installed connection.py does not even have validate_certs option.

We should:
- make the cert verification a config option
- look at supporting the cloud.pem for self-sign certs.

Simply turning this on in boto leads to this when trying to load the dashboard after login:

"Internal Server Error

The server encountered an unexpected internal server error

(generated by waitress)"

and this in the console log

SSLError: [Errno 1] _ssl.c:499: error:14090086:SSL routines:SSL3_GET_SERVER_CERTIFICATE:certificate verify failed
and this isn't caught by our default boto error handler. I'll have to see what we can do to catch this generically or make a call to test ssl access after login.
I want to point out that the login API call doesn't care about the SSL cert. We make that manually with urllib2 since boto doesn't support this euca-specific call.

[~rusvika], would this feature request require adding the ssl cert check to the STS call on login?

[~dkavanagh], were you testing with self-signed certificate? That might be the reason why verification failed.

And, yes, SSL certificate should be checked on all paths, especially when credentials are exchanged.

I've concluded that I need to port our STS code over to httplib (instead of urllib2) and then we can leverage the boto CertValidatingHTTPSConnection for authentication. For the rest of boto calls, that same code will already be used.

I'm skipping the SSL cert verification for AWS since they tend to have decent certs. I was having a real issue getting that to work, so I talked myself out of doing it.
I do have cert verification working for Euca by re-using boto code to do same at login, and enabling it for boto after login.
I just need a cloud with a good cert installed to test against! [~rusvika] ??

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/902

Notice the values in the default console.ini

# enables SSL certificate validation on communication to the cloud service endpoints.
# all communication to those services uses SSL already, but enabling this requires a properly signed cert.
connection.ssl.validation = false
# use this value to override the default cacerts.txt that comes with boto
#connection.ssl.certfile = cacerts.txt

By setting the first value to true, you can see the ssl validation error when loggin in to eucalyptus.
UX review passed, ready for code review.
@vika, yes, let's punt the AWS for this ticket and write another. I doubt we'll get that in for 4.0.2

[~dkavanagh], what was the problem with AWS? In my understanding, it should be no different than validating a CA-signed cert for Eucalyptus. Lets first test Euca with a CA-signed cert and see whether we run into the same problem.
[~dkavanagh], I believe euca2ools verify AWS' cert, it might be worth checking they do that.

[~rusvika], the difference is in how we handle the STS call for aws. In that case, it's signed on the client and issued in the proxy. I wasn't able to get that to work with httplib in several hours of trying, so I decided to punt. I'll check out how euca2ools does it.
Pull request 902 merged into maint-4.0 branch

[~rusvika], euca2ools relies on boto/requestbuilder, which relies on an SSL validation feature of urllib3. We've been using urllib2 which does not support this. I've tried converting to httplib so we can re-use boto/boto's ssl validation as I did for the eucalyptus STS call, but no luck. I may have to return to this so I don't pull in another dependency (urllib3) to solve this.

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/911

This contains the validation of certs when getting STS tokens from AWS
Pull request 911 merged
I'm self-rejecting since I found a problem with unresponsive CLC not being reported properly (on login).
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/941
Pull request 941 merged
Giving it back to David to add a missing config param passing.
Updated pull request (by [~dkavanagh]) at https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/965 has been merged
Passing to [~rusvika] to review
Passing it back to [~dkavanagh] because it looks like the connection.ssl.certfile is not properly propagated to boto.
I have a fix that I got working on your machine, [~rusvika]
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/987
[~dkavanagh], [~kgill], can this issue move into "In QA"?
Pull request 987
[~dkavanagh], is it console-specific issue with DNS? Are you investigating further?
I've tried to reproduce this using boto via the python shell. I get a perfectly normal response when I turns ssl verification off. When I turn it on, I get an SSL Cert error, not the DNSError.

The best info I've found yet is here:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12412701/intermittent-issues-while-accessing-external-http-services-using-gevent

The indications are that libevent tries to override httplib with it's own http client lib. That could explain why I see this inside the app, but not outside the app. [~kgill], have you heard of this?

I updated to gevent-1.0.1 from pypi and this started working. I've even re-enabled SSL cert validation. [~rusvika]

[~gholms], this issue I found (linked above) means that if we wish to use DNS names for service endpoints, we need to updated gevent. I think it also means we don't need libevent anymore, since newer gevent bundles libev
What's the chance we could address this for 4.0.2? cc:[~tjcramer]

Updating gevent is going to be non-trivial on RHEL 6 since a lot of stuff uses it.  I suspect it would not be horribly difficult to build a new package for gevent1, but that has not yet been scoped.  Either way, I advise against requiring a major dependency version bump for a sub-minor console release.
[~dkavanagh]: Good catch on the gevent issue.  I haven't observed that until now since I haven't used pre-1.0 gevent in a while (and not with Boto).
Punted this one to 4.1.0 to re-visit (re-test) when GUI-1339 is resolved.

[~alice], there's a process for installing an SSL cert on the CLC. (https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0.2/index.html#security-guide/config_ssl_ufs.html)
If you do this with a self-signed cert, then you need to take your ca.crt file and append it to the cacerts.txt file on the console (which is /usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/boto/cacerts/cacerts.txt), or you can use your own cacerts.txt file by setting the console.ini connection.ssl.certfile setting.
I had a heck of a time verifying this myself, to be honest.

[~dkavanagh], do I interpret it correctly that you verified/confirmed that the fix works? In that case, is testing still needed? [~alice], feel free to assign this one to me for testing (most likely for 4.1.1, not 4.1.0).

Yes, and I recall a lot of trouble initially testing. Then once we got a new gevent worker, I tested further. We should be good now, but I'm not sure about that DNS name issue you mentioned on Oct 6th.

[~dkavanagh], [~alice]: I also tried setting connection.ssl.validation = true and I still get the certificate warning message.  I also tried the steps mentioned in the ticket to get this to work and that didn't seem to help.  Has this changed?  If not, I may need more guidance to get this to work.
What is critical to this is having the gevent1 package installed from our repo. This allows the SSL validation to work.
[~dkavanagh]: I checked and the python-gevent1 package was already installed.  Anything else I need to try?

I also seem to remember needing the DNS name of the CLC and using that when generating the SSL cert. Then put that into the console.ini at clchost. 
Then, it was a real pain to get the proper cert into the cacerts.txt file. If you override that location in the console.ini, I can't remember if an absolute path was needed.

[~dkavanagh]: I have tried many times to get this to work.  I have generated my own SSL files, followed these steps: https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0.2/index.html#security-guide/config_ssl_ufs.html and modified the cacerts.txt file according to the instructions.  At this point, I am unable to test this.  I will continue trying to figure this out but I may need more help.

[~dkavanagh]: OK, I was finally able to get this to work, however, I was curious about one thing.  If the certificate is valid on the server side, I was able to login to the UI.  However, it also let me login if the client's certificate to the server was invalid, is that proper behavior or should it also not allow you to login if the client's certificate is invalid to the server?  Is that even possible to do?
[~ccassler], this feature was strictly about verifying the server SSL cert (from the UFS). The process to setup SSL for the client is different and unrelated.

I verified this by creating a valid and invalid cacerts.txt file.  The valid file matched the cert that was signed when creating the clc certificate.   The invalid certificate matched the certificate created on the clc used in /etc/eucaconsole.  When the "connection.ssl.validation" was set to true, I was not able to login using the invalid cert.  I was able to login when I used the valid cert.  When I set the "connection.ssl.validation" to "true", I was able to login regardless of the cert.

Thanks for sticking with it, Casey!
